Question 1 Consider a system of linear equations [latex]P X = Q [/latex] where [latex]P \in \mathbb{R}^{3 \times 3} [/latex] and [latex]Q \in \mathbb{R}^{3 \times 1} [/latex].  
Suppose [latex]P [/latex] has an [latex]LU [/latex] decomposition, [latex]P = LU [/latex], where [latex] L = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ l_{21} & 1 & 0 \\ l_{31} & l_{32} & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad U = \begin{bmatrix} u_{11} & u_{12} & u_{13} \\ 0 & u_{22} & u_{23} \\ 0 & 0 & u_{33} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] Which of the following statement(s) is/are TRUE?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: The system [latex]P X = Q [/latex] can be solved by first solving [latex]L Y = Q [/latex] and then [latex]U X = Y [/latex].
options.B: If [latex]P [/latex] is invertible, then both [latex]L [/latex] and [latex]U [/latex] are invertible.
options.C: If [latex]P [/latex] is singular, then at least one of the diagonal elements of [latex]U [/latex] is zero.
options.D: If [latex]P [/latex] is symmetric, then both [latex]L [/latex] and [latex]U [/latex] are symmetric.
